awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Excited State Dynamics of Structurally Precise Metal Nanoclusters
awd_abstract_narration:
These awards by the Macromolecular/Supramolecular/Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry to Christine Aikens (Kansas State University), Ken Knappenberger (Florida State University), and Chris Ackerson (Colorado State University) develop the ability to predict how metal particles with dimensions on the order of one-billionth of a meter (i.e., nanoparticles) interact with light. Such metal nanoparticles may, in the long term, become functional components in solar-to-electric energy conversion devices, optical sensors, and medical diagnostics and therapeutics, among others. Currently, the lack of understanding how light provokes energy flow through these materials limits their applications. The collaborative team combines cutting-edge theoretical and experimental spectroscopy along with precision nanoparticle synthesis and characterization. They facilitate their multi-disciplinary research project by developing graduate student training courses focused on modeling, measurement, and preparation of structurally precise photonic nanoparticles. The team is also strongly engaged in outreach to K-12 students and educators; is actively involved in incorporating research into the undergraduate curricula at each of their respective universitie;, and is committed to the involvement of underrepresented students in scientific research and education.

The primary thrusts of this effort are to determine how electronic energy relaxation affects the nanophotonic properties of structurally precise metal nanoparticles in the 1-2 nm size domain. The research features an emergent class of nanophotonic materials: monolayer-protected clusters (MPCs), which can be synthesized and isolated with atomic precision. These materials represent an intermediate class of materials between bulk metallic materials and smaller photo-excited molecules.  The program of study provides nanoparticle-specific descriptions for fundamental processes involved such as electron-phonon coupling, which are critical for determining the functional properties of nanophotonic materials. The research investigates the interplay between MPC structural parameters and electronic relaxation. The specific objectives are: 1) to determine the mechanisms of electron-phonon and electron-vibrational coupling and their influence on the electronic relaxation dynamics of Au25(SR)18 MPCs, where SR is an alkanethiol; 2) to understand the effects of metal doping on MPC dynamics; 3) to describe how electron-phonon coupling changes with increasing MPC dimensions; and 4) to investigate the influence of MPC ligand band structure on electron dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Metal nanoparticles and their assemblies can be used to control energy for many important applications, including solar-to-electric energy conversion, medical diagnostics and therapeutics, molecular and virus detection, and optical data transfer. Most recently, we have focused our efforts on understanding how atomic-level structure influences electronic spin properties, which can be impactful for quantum information sciences. Our research under this award has led to many key new understandings of how metal structure on the atomic to nanometer length scale affects fundamental electronic and magnetic properties related to these applications. In order to make these advances, it has been necessary for our research team to develop new experimental capabilities that provide atomic-level descriptions of metals. Some examples of our advances in experimental capabilities include the development of ultrafast spectrometers that provide temporal resolutions of electronic spin conversion and electron-vibrational coupling (10-15 to 10-12 seconds). Other examples include the development of energy- and time-domain measurements that use high applied magnetic fields (17 T), which are approximately 1700x larger than a common refrigerator magnet. This approach has allowed us to resolve details about electron spin in metals, which can be important for spintronics and other quantum information applications. Our breakthroughs in experimental measurements have been described in several peer-reviewed publications and research presentations at universities, scientific conferences, and national laboratories.

I will highlight key findings that occurred in two primary areas during the activities related to this award. They include describing spin-conversion processes in atomically precise nanoclusters and understanding mechanisms that lead to large degrees of spin polarization in metals.

We studied electronic spin-state dynamics for Au25(SC8H9)18q and Au24Pd(SC8H9)18 MPCs. These clusters were chosen for study because Au25(SC8H9)18-1 is a closed-shell superatomic cluster, but they can be switched from paramagnetic to ferromagnetic behavior by electrochemical oxidation. We used a femtosecond time-resolved circularly polarized transient-absorption spectroscopy (fs-CPTA) method developed in our lab that allowed us to isolate the dynamics of different spin quantum fine structure states. fs-CPTA measurements revealed multiple spin-polarized transient signals for neutral (open shell) Au25(SC8H9)18, following 1.82-eV excitation, which persisted for several picoseconds. These observations of cluster-specific dynamics resulted from spin-polarized superatom P to D excitation, via an unpaired Pz electron of the open-shell seven-electron Au25(SC8H9)18 MPC. These results are very encouraging, and suggest that once developed, quantum metal clusters may serve as structurally well-defined prototypes for understanding spin and quantum state dynamics in quantum metals.  

Building on our research on nanocluster spin-state dynamics, we have also worked to understand if material structure can be used to control the emission properties of these systems with a specific emphasis on achieving large degrees of spin polarization. We learned that MPCs support multiple emission channels – unlike most molecules and nanoparticles – which each exhibit unique optical properties (i.e. lifetimes, emission frequencies, quantum yields, and degrees of circular polarization (DOCP). We observed state-specific spin-polarized emission for the Au25(SC8H9)18 MPC (Figure 1) and its Pd-substituted analog. Through analysis of emission measurements in magnetic fields, we learned that the extent of spin-polarization is determined by state-specific electron-vibration coupling strengths and energy separations of bright and dark electronic fine-structure levels. At low temperatures (<60K), metal-metal superatom-based intraband transitions dominates the PL emission. At higher temperatures (>60 K), interband ligand-based emission dominates. In the low-temperature PL regime, increased sample temperature resulted in larger global PL intensity. In the high-temperature regime, increased temperature quenched interband radiative recombination. These outcomes are important because they provide information about which MPC structural components should be modified to achieve specific optical properties. Perhaps most importantly, the results taught us that for room-temperature operation, the ligand shell structure will have the largest influence on the nanocluster optical properties.

A practical outcome of this work is that we have demonstrated that large degrees of spin polarization can be achieved in quantum metals when their structure is controlled at the atomic level. In the case of a twenty-five-atom gold cluster, we achieved 35% spin polarization, which is competitive with typical values for leading quantum materials. Once refined, these properties can be used for quantum information applications.

I also contributed to education in spectroscopy and nanoscience. This work resulted in the graduation of three PhD and several undergraduate students, all of whom are now gainfully employed in academic, industrial, and government sectors. On an international level, I taught courses on spectroscopy and nanomaterials at Politecnico di Milano, KU Leuven, and the Indian Institute of Technology - Kanpur. I also advised the masters theses of two students at Politecnico di Milano, who worked with me to study electron dynamics in metal nanoclusters.
